questions.text: A newly joined trainee at the gymnasium was able to lift about 8 Kilograms of weight using both his upper limbs. When two more kilograms were added, he could not resist and had dropped the weight down. Which receptor and nerve fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight?

choices.text: Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber
Golgi tendon organ and Ia fiber

questions.solution:
The Golgi tendon organ and Ib fiber are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Here, in the scenario given, two types of physiological reflexes have happened.

  • Stretch reflex/myotatic reflex - This has been responsible for the ability to bear the initial 8 kgs of weight by the trainee.
  • Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex - When two more kgs have been added, this has brought the inhibition of motor neuron discharge to his muscles which are responsible for his inability to bear the weight.

Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/ Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite of the stretch reflex.

When the tension on the muscle becomes extreme, the inhibitory effect from the Golgi tendon organ, carried by Ib afferents, leads to instantaneous relaxation of the entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction.

It is a protective mechanism to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone.

Note: Muscle spindles senses changes in muscle length (stretch).

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety?
questions.solution:
The Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG) has a biological activity similar to that of Luteinizing Hormone (LH).

hCG is a glycoprotein produced by syncytiotrophoblast. It is made up of α and β subunits. Though the α subunit of hCG is similar to the α subunits of LH, FSH, and TSH, the β subunit has structural similarity to LH only. Hence, LH is a better answer than FSH. 

hCG is primarily luteinizing and luteotrophic. It appears to act on the same receptor as that of LH. The function of hCG is to prevent regression of the corpus luteum. It can be detected in blood as early as 6 days after conception and forms the basis of various tests used to identify pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following stimulates renin secretion from the juxtaglomerular cells?

choices.text: Increased Sodium and Chloride concentration in the distal renal tubule

questions.solution:
Unilateral renal artery stenosis is associated with increased renin secretion.

The arterial stenosis reduces the blood pressure in the afferent arterioles which in turn stimulates renin secretion through the intrarenal baroreceptor mechanism. This mechanism causes an increase in renin secretion when the arteriolar pressure at the level of juxtaglomerular (JG) cells falls and vice-versa. The increased renin secretion leads to secondary renal hypertension which is also known as Goldblatt hypertension.

Other options:

Option A: The renin secretion is inversely proportional to the amount of sodium and chloride ions in the distal renal tubules. Thus an increase in these concentrations causes a decrease in renin secretion.

Option B: Increased level of vasopressin leads to inhibition of renin secretion.

Option D: Increased level of angiotensin II inhibits the secretion of renin via direct action on JG cells.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except:
questions.solution:
All of the above increase gastric acid secretion except serotonin.

Serotonin is localized in the enterochromaffin cells of the gastrointestinal (GI) mucosa and within neurons of the GI tract. Serotonin inhibits gastric acid secretion. It stimulates the production and release of gastric and colonic mucus. Serotonin acts as an enteric neurotransmitter and increases intestinal motility.

The main factors that stimulate gastric secretion are acetylcholine, gastrin, and histamine. Parasympathetic stimulation releases Ach which stimulates the secretion of

  • pepsinogen by peptic cells
  • hydrochloric acid by parietal cells
  • mucus by mucous cells.

Both gastrin and histamine strongly stimulate acid secretion by parietal cells but have little effect on other cells.

The stomach mucosa has two important types of tubular glands:

  • The oxyntic (gastric) glands secrete hydrochloric acid, pepsinogen, intrinsic factor, and mucus.
  • The pyloric glands secrete mainly mucus for protection of the pyloric mucosa from the stomach acid. They also secrete the hormone gastrin.

Note- Serotonin released from the small intestine triggers vomiting by stimulation of 5HT3 receptors. Therefore, 5HT3 antagonists like ondansetron are used as antiemetics.

questions.text: A normal healthy adult participated in a respiratory study that was conducted to understand the respiratory functions. In the upright position, an increase in all of the following parameters can be seen with respect to the base of the lungs except?
questions.solution:
In the upright position, an increase in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q ratio) is not seen with respect to the base of the lungs. At the base of the lung, the V/Q ratio is decreased. 

V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q) for the lungs at rest. The average value of the V/Q ratio throughout the lungs is 0.8. When this ratio is mismatched, it can cause CO2 retention (when solely, ventilation is impaired) or lowered arterial O2 (when perfusion is impaired). 

Normally, in the upright position, the V/Q ratio in the normal lungs markedly undergoes changes from the apex to the base due to the effect of gravity as shown below - 

At the base of the lung:

Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity.

Increased ventilation is due to the increase in intrapleural pressure compared to the apex, thereby making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference less at the base. Thus, due to this low-pressure difference, the lung is less expanded compared to the apex. This makes the ventilation per unit volume rise as the lung expansion is relatively small. 

The alveolar pressure also decreases thus reducing the compression of the vessels and increasing the pulmonary blood flow at the base. An increase in perfusion is more than an increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, the ratio decreases.

At the apex (against gravity):

Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity.

The reason for decreased ventilation is that at the start of inspiration, intrapleural pressure is more negative thus making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference increase at the apex. The apex is above the level of the heart and capillary pressure at the apex is close to atmospheric pressure thus decreasing the blood flow. But, a decrease in perfusion is higher than a decrease in ventilation. Hence, the ratio increases.

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury in the area supplied by the middle cerebral artery. Which of the following functional areas of the brain is least likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Primary visual area is supplied by the posterior cerebral artery and hence is least likely to be affected here.

A vascular injury to the middle cerebral artery affects the lateral area of cortex mainly. All the other options in the question are supplied by the middle cerebral artery.

The blood supply of the brain:

  • Blood is mainly supplied by Internal Carotid artery and vertebrobasilar arteries.
  • Cortical supply is mainly by cortical arteries (Anterior, Middle and Posterior).

Anterior Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure
  • Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Middle Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure
  • Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Posterior Cerebral Artery

  • Course - Curves behind the midbrain
  • Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

questions.text:
The structures involved in the auditory pathway are -
  1. Superior olivary nucleus
  2. Nucleus of the medial lemniscus
  3. Superior colliculus 
  4. Medial geniculate body
  5. Superior temporal gyrus
questions.solution:
The structures involved in the auditory pathway are 1, 4, and 5, i.e, the superior olivary nucleus, medial geniculate body, and superior temporal gyrus.

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is -

  1. Vestibulocochlear nerve
  2. Cochlear nucleus
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex - superior temporal gyrus

questions.text: An elderly patient was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease and was started on beta-blockers. However, the patient continued to have symptoms despite it's use. He was then started on ivabradine. This drug improves the symptoms of angina by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ivabradine decreases the automaticity in the sinoatrial node and thus reduces the heart rate. This reduction in the heart rate decreases the myocardial oxygen demand.

The oxygen requirement of the heart mainly depends on the work done by the heart. This work mainly depends on cardiac output and peripheral resistance. An increase in these parameters will increase the oxygen requirement of the heart.

Important determinants of cardiac output are:

Stroke volume- It is the amount of blood pumped out of the heart during each heartbeat. This stroke volume increases whenever, there is increased venous return to the heart, increased end-diastolic volume (preload), and increased contractility. Contractility further depends on the initial length of the cardiac muscle fiber and the autonomic innervation.

Heart rate- Increased heart rate increases the cardiac output which in turn increases the oxygen requirement. Heart rate is controlled primarily by the autonomic nerves, with sympathetic stimulation increasing the rate and parasympathetic stimulation decreasing the rate.

Afterload- The tension at which the load is lifted is called afterload. As the afterload increases, the heart has to work more in order to pump blood to the organs. This in turn results in increased oxygen requirement. It is dependent on the peripheral resistance. 

Drugs used in the management of angina either decrease the work done by the heart or increases the blood flow to the heart.

  • Nitrates- They increase the cGMP and cause venodilation. It mainly results in an increase in venous capacitance and a decrease in the ventricular preload. They might also increase coronary flow in some areas and in variant anginas.
  • Calcium channel blockers- Blocking the calcium channels leads to the relaxation of vascular smooth muscles and decreased impulses in the conduction system. This leads to decreased peripheral resistance, decreased blood pressure, decreased contractility, decreased heart rate, and decreased oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Beta-blockers- They decrease the oxygen requirement by decreasing the heart rate, blood pressure, and contractility. Some drugs like carvedilol and nebivolol also cause vasodilation.

Newer antianginal drugs

  • Ranolazine- It inhibits the late sodium current and reduces the intracellular calcium concentration. It reduces diastolic tension, cardiac contractility, and work.
  • Trimetazidine- inhibits the fatty acid oxidation in the myocardium. It decreases the oxygen requirement of the heart.
  • Ivabradine- decreases the heart rate and decreases oxygen requirement.
  • Fasudil- It is a Rho kinase inhibitor. It is useful in coronary vasospasm.

questions.text: The fourth heart sound is caused by:

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
The fourth heart sound is caused by ventricular filling. The atrial contraction against the stiff ventricle produces an audible S4 sound

During ventricular filling, the atria contract to push blood into the ventricles. In conditions where the ventricular walls are stiff or hypertrophied, such as in conditions like hypertrophic cardiomyopathy or systemic hypertension, the atrial contraction against the stiff ventricle produces an audible S4 sound.

During the cardiac cycle, there are two main phases: diastole and systole. Diastole is the relaxation phase when the chambers fill with blood, while systole is the contraction phase when the chambers pump blood out.

The fourth heart sound (S4) occurs during diastole, specifically late diastole, just before the first heart sound (S1). It is caused by atrial contraction, which happens as the atria forcefully contract to push the remaining blood into the non-compliant or hypertrophied ventricle.

questions.text: In ORS, sodium is given along with glucose to facilitate___?
questions.solution:
In ORS, sodium is given along with glucose to facilitate co-transport.

Glucose co transported with sodium is an example of Secondary Active transport.

The glucose-dependent sodium and water absorption is the principle behind replacing glucose and sodium in a 1:1 molar ratio in the WHO oral rehydration solution (ORS). The low osmolarity of the ORS in the lumen as compared to the blood facilitate absorption of fluid and hence the electrolytes due to the solvent drag.

The low-osmolality World Health Organization (WHO) oral rehydration solution (ORS) is now the global standard of care in the management of acute gastroenteritis. 

Note:

Types of transport:

  • Active transport:
    • Primary
      • Energy is derived from the transporter itself. Eg Na+ K+ ATPase pump.
    • Secondary:
      • Energy is derived indirectly. Eg. SGLT – Sodium linked glucose transport
  • Passive transport
    • Simple:
      • No energy is required.
      • No carrier molecule is involved.
      • Eg. O2 exchange in alveoli.
    • Facilitated:
      • No energy is required.
      • Carrier molecule involved.
      • Eg. Glucose transport by GLUT transporters.

Related Pearl: Composition of reduced osmolarity Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS)

Sodium  75

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).

Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of the toes.

 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

 

Other signs as seen in patients with UMN lesions are spasticity, hypertonia and hyperreflexia. 

Related Pearl: Features of Motor Neuron Lesions

Upper Motor Neuron Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron Lesion

Upper motor neuron typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons

Lower motor neurons are those whose axons terminate on skeletal muscles

Little or no muscle wasting . UMN lesions result in weakness of relatively large group of muscles

Muscle atrophy → muscle weakness of an individual and specific muscle

Hypertonia

Hypotonia

Increased or exaggerated deep tendon reflexes (hyperreflexia)

Hyporeflexia or areflexia

Spasticity

Flaccidity

Positive Babinski sign (abnormal plantar extensor reflex)

Fasciculations

questions.text: A 65-year-old-lady with CKD presents with bilateral limb muscle weakness and fasciculations. On investigation, her serum potassium level was found to be 6 mEq/L. What is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features?

choices.text: Resting membrane potential of nerves is hyperpolarised
Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential
Resting membrane potential moved away from action potential threshold

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the serum potassium levels of 6 mEq/L (normal levels: 3.5-5) is suggestive of hyperkalemia. Resting membrane potential moved closer to the threshold potential is the likely mechanism to have caused her clinical features. 

Resting membrane potential (RMP) is the difference in the electrical potentials between the cytoplasm of the cell and the extracellular space. 

At rest, there are more open K+ channels compared to Na+ channels, thus the membrane permeability of K+ is greater. As a result of this, the intracellular and extracellular K+ concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP. Furthermore, the RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of K+ in general. 

In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential leading to a more excitable nerve. The excitable nerve, stimulates the muscle repeatedly causing fasciculations, exhaustion of muscle, and weakness.

In hypokalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is reduced. Thus the RMP is reduced and the neuron is hyperpolarized.

questions.text: In ECG tracings,  sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are typically seen in

choices.text: Recording done with paper speed of 12.5 mm/s
Recording done with paper speed of 50 mm/s

questions.solution:
Sharp irregular spikes of the baseline that are particularly prominent in the limb leads are seen in a patient that is not relaxed. 

Though the ECG recorders are configured to pick up the electrical frequency generated by the heart better, they also detect the contractions of skeletal muscles. So, unless the patient is relaxed and lying down comfortably, the tracing may show some skeletal muscle activity.

Ex:- 

A patient that is shivering due to cold, or one that has involuntary movements due to conditions like Parkinson's, etc would cause spikes in the baseline of the ECG.

In the case of shivering, the spikes would be more exaggerated and synchronized than that seen in a patient that is not adequately relaxed, because of the skeletal muscle groups contracting together in case of shivering.

Other options:

  • Patients with hypothyroidism would show bradycardia, low voltage QRS complexes, and widespread T-wave inversions.
  • The recording is normally done with a paper speed of 25 mm/s.
    • Recording at 12.5 mm/s, which is slower than normal, would cause QRS complex that are close together (creating the false impression of a rapid heart rate) and P waves, QRS complexes, and T waves that are narrow and spiky
    • Recording at 50 mm/s, which is faster than normal, would produce longer intervals between QRS complexes (creating the false impression of a slow heart rate), widened QRS complexes, and an apparently long QT interval.

questions.text: The image below depicts which of the following types of cell-to-cell signaling?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the paracrine cell-to-cell signaling mechanism. In paracrine signaling, the signaling molecules released by a cell only affect target cells in close proximity to it.

An example of paracrine signaling is the release of endothelin-1, a potent vasoconstrictor released by the endothelial cells.

Synaptic signaling is a special case of paracrine signaling (for chemical synapses) between neurons and target cells.

Other options:

Option B: In the autocrine signaling mechanism, the cells respond to the signaling molecules that are released by themselves, which is the site of release and action within the same cell. Note that the signaling molecules are first secreted out of the cell and then act on the same cell through receptors. An example is the proliferation of activated T-cells by IL-2 released by the same cell after it interacts with antigen-presenting cells.

Option C: In endocrine signaling, a signaling molecule, a hormone (for example insulin, FSH, LH), is usually carried by the blood from its site of release to act on its target at a distance.

The below image shows the different types of extracellular cell-to-cell communication mechanisms.

Option D: Merocrine is a type of glandular secretion and not an extracellular signaling mechanism. In this, the secretions are poured out by exocytosis and the cell remains intact. An example of the merocrine gland is the goblet cell and eccrine sweat gland.

An illustration depicting this mechanism is given below.

Which among the following options depict the correct match between the substances (column A) and their site of production (column B)?

ii. Erythropoietin b. Proximal tubule cells

questions.solution:
The correct match is (i-b), (ii-d), (iii-a), (iv-c).

Hormones produced by the kidney are:

1. Renin- It is produced by juxtaglomerular cells. It converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. Factors that affect renin secretion are:

Stimulatory Inhibitory

Increased sympathetic activity

Increased circulating catecholamines

Conditions those increase renin secretion are:

  • Na+ depletion
  • Diuretics
  • Hypotension
  • Hemorrhage
  • Upright posture
  • Dehydration
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cirrhosis

2. Erythropoietin- the majority of the erythropoietin is produced from interstitial cells in the peritubular capillary bed of the kidneys. Some amount is produced by the perivenous hepatocytes in the liver. It is released in response to hypoxia, cobalt salts, and androgens. It increases red cell production.

3. 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol- The 25-hydroxycholecalciferol produced in the liver is further converted to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol by the proximal tubular cells. This is also called calcitriol. It increases the calcium reabsorption from the kidneys, intestine, and increases the activity of osteoblasts.

Note- Angiotensinogen is synthesized in the liver. It is converted to angiotensin I by renin. Its circulating level is increased by glucocorticoids, thyroid hormones, estrogens, several cytokines, and angiotensin II.

questions.text: A medical student was studying about the principle sensory modalities. Under which of the following category of receptors can he classify the Ruffini's corpuscles?
questions.solution:
Ruffini corpuscles are a part of cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are located in the dermis of both glabrous and hairy skin. They comprise of enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules and respond to stretch and fluttering vibrations. 

Mechanoreceptors are a type of sensory receptor that detects mechanical compression, stretching at the receptor or tissue adjacent to the receptors. 

The following are examples of mechanoreceptors :

Skin tactile sensibilities (epidermis and dermis)

• Free nerve endings

• Expanded tip endings

       Merkel’s discs and other variants

• Spray endings

• Ruffini’s endings

• Encapsulated endings

       Meissner’s corpuscles and Krause’s corpuscles

• Hair end-organs

Deep tissue sensibilities

 

• Free nerve endings

• Expanded tip endings

• Spray endings

          Ruffini’s endings

• Encapsulated endings

          Pacinian corpuscles and other variants

• Muscle endings

           Muscle spindles

          Golgi tendon receptors
Hearing • Sound receptors of cochlea
Equilibrium • Vestibular receptors 
Arterial pressure • Baroreceptors of carotid sinuses and aorta


Other Options:

Option A: Thermoreceptors are cold and warm receptors

Option C: Chemoreceptors are found in carotid and aortic bodies

Option D: Electromagnetic receptors are found in the eye as rods and cones

questions.text: Spermatogenesis is maintained by which hormone?
questions.solution:
All three of them (testosterone, FSH, LH) are required for spermatogenesis.

Pulses of hypothalamic GnRH stimulate the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH, which then act on the testes

FSH acts on the Sertoli cells to stimulate spermatogenesis and inhibin secretion. LH acts on the Leydig cells to stimulate testosterone secretion. Testosterone, acting locally on the Sertoli cells, is essential for maintaining spermatogenesis.

questions.text: An obstetrician elicits a reflex by performing a procedure for labour induction on a patient as depicted in the image below. What type of homeostatic feedback mechanism is associated with this reflex?
questions.solution:
The procedure done in the image above to induce labour is the stripping of membranes which elicits the Ferguson reflex. Ferguson's reflex is associated with a positive feedback mechanism.

Stripping/Sweeping of membranes refers to the digital separation of the chorioamniotic membranes from the lower uterine segment and cervix wall. It is associated with an increase in blood levels of prostaglandin F2α metabolite, also known as dinoprost. 

Positive feedback is a type of feedback in which the initial stimulus triggers a response that deviates further from the original state.

The fetal ejection reflex (Ferguson reflex) is a phenomenon in which mechanical stretching of the internal cervix enhances uterine activity. Oxytocin is released as the fetal head presses on the uterine cervix, which further enhances uterine contraction. This finally helps in the delivery of the fetus by facilitating fetal head descent. It is an example of a positive feedback mechanism.

Other options:

Option A: Negative feedback mechanism- If the activity of a particular system is increased, the controller system initiates the negative feedback mechanism, which prevents overactivity and ensures normal homeostasis (e.g., baroreceptor reflex). 

Option B: Feedforward control also called anticipatory control (option C), is that which makes an anticipatory or adaptive response without a specific stimulus. This is seen in body temperature regulation where thermoregulatory responses are initiated by the hypothalamus before the changes in environmental temperature change the core body temperature. Thus, shivering in response to a cold environment is an example of feedforward control.

questions.text: A person after having a meal had a sense of fullness and feels that he can no longer eat. Which area of the hypothalamus acts as the centre for the given physiological process?
questions.solution:
The physiological process explained in the question stem is that of satiety. The ventromedial nucleus of the hypothalamus acts as the centre for satiety.

A centre that reduces the desire for food is known as a satiety centre. These centres are sensitive to blood glucose concentration and cause satiety in hyperglycemic states. The hypothalamic areas that regulate satiety are:

  • Ventromedial nucleus 
  • Arcuate nucleus (also acts as a centre for hunger)
  • Paraventricular nucleus (also regulates oxytocin release and water conservation)

Other options:

Option A: Supraoptic nucleus regulates vasopressin release.

Option B: Medial preoptic area regulates bladder contraction, heart rate and blood pressure.

Option D: Lateral hypothalamic area is responsible for causing thirst and eating. It also stimulates rage and fighting.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years presents with vomiting and abdominal pain. On examination, she appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed pH - 7.00, blood sugar level- 500 mg/dL, and ketonuria. What type of breathing pattern can be observed in this case?

choices.text: Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief insufficient release.
Regular deep respirations with periods of apnea

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with severe dehydration, hyperglycemia, ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis(pH-7.00) is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. The type of breathing pattern that can be seen in a case of diabetic ketoacidosis is a deep and rapid breathing pattern (Kussmaul breathing).

Normally, the H+ ions from acids in our body are buffered with various mechanisms. But in cases where acid production is high like in diabetic ketoacidosis and sepsis, the buffering capacity is exceeded. The resulting acidosis stimulates respiration and decreases alveolar CO2 in order to produce a compensatory fall in the H+ ions.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is the most serious complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The triad of DKA includes hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. Clinical manifestations of diabetic ketoacidosis include dehydration, tachypnea with deep, sighing respiration (Kussmaul breathing), nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, confusion, and drowsiness.

Patients with DKA typically have:

  • Hyperglycemia (blood glucose >250 mg/dl)
  • Venous pH < 7.3 or serum bicarbonate <18 mmol/L
  • Ketonemia or ketonuria

Signs of ketoacidosis: 

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid breathing)
  • Fruity breath odor (acetone)
  • Prolonged Q-T interval
  • Diminished neurocognitive function
  • Coma
Other options:
 
Option A: Apneusis is characterized by deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief insufficient release. It is seen in mid-pontine level lesions with cut vagi.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option C: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man exercises at a high altitude. Which of the following changes would occur in him?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, there will be a rise in urinary bicarbonate levels if a person is observed exercising at a high altitude.

Adaptation at High Altitudes:

  • The work capacity is reduced at high altitudes and this reduction is in direct proportion to the decrease in O2 uptake.
  • Immediate exposure to low PO2 at higher altitudes stimulates the arterial chemoreceptors, and this stimulation increases alveolar ventilation.
  • This immediate increase in pulmonary ventilation upon rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of CO2, reducing the PCO2 and increasing the pH of the body fluids causing respiratory alkalosis (not metabolic - option A). This raised pH inhibits the brainstem respiratory center and opposes the increased ventilation. So, respiratory alkalosis will hinder maximal exercise effort.
  • To compensate for this respiratory alkalosis, kidneys reduce hydrogen ion secretion and increase bicarbonate excretion. This reduces plasma and cerebrospinal fluid bicarbonate concentration and brings the pH toward normal. It removes the inhibitory effect of alkalosis on respiration. Hence fall in blood bicarbonate facilitates the exercise effort.
  • Lactic acid levels increase which causes extreme fatigue. When there is insufficient oxygen (at high altitudes), most of the pyruvic acid is converted into lactic acid, which diffuses out of the muscle cells into the interstitial fluid and blood.

questions.text: An agglutination test was done to identify blood groups in several people. Subjects with which of the following findings are called universal blood recipients?
questions.solution:
The agglutination test in image 2 corresponds to the AB-positive blood group. The AB-positive blood group is the universal recipient type. 

Blood typing or blood matching is done before transfusions to avoid incompatibility. Red blood cells (RBC) are first separated from plasma and diluted with saline solution for an agglutination test. Anti-A and anti-B agglutinins are added to different portions. If RBCs are clumped/agglutinated, then an antigen-antibody reaction has occurred.

Antigens A and B are seen on the surfaces of the red blood cells. Depending on inheritance, people have one or both on the surface of their cells. When neither of them is present, the blood type is O. Based on the antigens present, blood is classified into four main types: O (OO), A (OA/AA), B (OB/BB), and AB. 

When the A or B agglutinins are absent in the body, corresponding anti-agglutinins (anti-A or anti-B) are found in the plasma. Those with AB blood group have no circulating anti-agglutinins and do not develop transfusion reactions due to ABO incompatibility. Therefore, people with type AB blood are called universal recipients. They are also considered universal plasma donors.

Rh type system is also essential for blood transfusion. The difference with the A-B-O system is that the antibodies to Rh antigen in people without Rh antigen occur after exposure and not spontaneously. 

Other options:

Option A: The given agglutination test is suggestive of O positive blood type. 

Option C: The test result shows agglutination with anti-A agglutinin and suggests blood type A negative.

Option D: The given test result shows no agglutination and suggests blood type O negative. People with blood type O negative are considered as universal donors.

questions.text:
An EEG conducted during sleep in a normal individual is given below. Identify the most likely change in neurotransmitters in the highlighted period.

EEG: Electroencephalogram
questions.solution:
In the given EEG, waves highlighted in red show the typical saw-tooth appearance of rapid eye movement (REM) sleep. The most likely change in neurotransmitters during this period is an increase in acetylcholine.

The other change in neurotransmitters during REM sleep is a decrease in serotonin and norepinephrine. 

An EEG is a recording that represents the electrical activity of the brain. It is used in localizing neuropathological lesions.

The brainstem ascending arousal system is composed of several groups of neurons like:

  • Locus coeruleus secrets norepinephrine
  • Raphe nucleus  secretes serotonin
  • Pontine nucleus secretes acetylcholine

During wakefulness, the locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are dominant and the pontine is suppressed. Therefore, when a person is awake the norepinephrine and serotonin are increased and acetylcholine is decreased. There is also decreased GABA and increased histamine during wakefulness.

REM sleep occurs when the pontine nucleus is dominant and locus coeruleus and raphe nucleus are suppressed. Therefore acetylcholine is increased and norepinephrine and serotonin are decreased. 

NREM (non-rapid eye movement) sleep occurs when there is suppression of the thalamus and cortex due to an increase in GABA and a decrease in histamine. 

Other options: Increase in serotonin, norepinephrine, and histamine is seen during wakefulness.

questions.text: Which of the following oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves corresponds to blood during resting conditions (dark blue line) and blood during exercise ( light blue line)?
questions.solution:
In the exercise, several factors shift the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve to the right, which serves to deliver extra amounts of O2 to the exercising muscle.

These factors include increasing the amount of CO2 released from the muscle tissue, increased H+ concentration in the muscle capillary blood, and increased temperature resulting from heat generated by the exercising muscle.

The right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin curve allows more oxygen to be released to the muscle at a given Po2 in the blood.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid-shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilise O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anaemia - reduced affinity for O2

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of irritability, increased sweating, and weight loss of around 6 kgs for the last 3 months. On examination, the patient has tachycardia and enlarged neck mass which moves with deglutition. An image of the patient is shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the hormone elevated in this patient?
  1. T4 has a longer half-life than T3
  2. T3 is more in concentration than T4
  3. This hormone binds to nuclear receptors
  4. Iodine transporter is also present in pituitary gland
  5. Drugs used in this condition primarily act by inhibiting deiodinase
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Graves disease. Thyroid hormone is elevated in this patient. Statements 1 and 3 are true regarding the thyroid hormone.

Synthesis- Iodine is required for the synthesis of thyroid hormone. Absorbed iodine is taken by the thyroid follicular cells with the help of a sodium iodide transporter (NIS). NIS is mainly present in the thyroid gland, but it can also be present in salivary glands, lactating breast, and placenta. NIS is not present in the pituitary gland.

The iodine that enters the thyroid gland undergoes organification and is added to tyrosyl residues within thyroglobulin. These iodotyrosines are then coupled to form T4 and T3 hormones. This reaction is catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. After coupling, the thyroglobulin is taken back into the cells to release T4 and T3. Uncoupled mono and diiodotyrosines are deiodinated by the enzyme dehalogenase to recycle iodine.

T3 and T4 are the two forms of the hormone. T4 is present in higher concentrations and has a longer half-life than T3. However, T3 is more potent than T4.

Thyroid hormones enter the cell by passive diffusion or by the transporters. On entering the cell, they bind to the nuclear thyroid hormone receptors. On binding to the receptors, they either stimulate or inhibit transcription.

Methimazole, carbimazole and propylthiouracil are the drugs used in the management of hyperthyroidism. They act by inhibiting thyroid peroxidase. In addition to this, propylthiouracil also inhibits the deiodination of T4 → T3. 

Drugs that prevent deiodination of T4 to T3 are propylthiouracil, propranolol, amiodarone, and oral cholecystographic agents.

questions.text: What is the next step in excitation-contraction coupling after the power stroke in skeletal muscle contraction?

choices.text: Cessation of calcium release from sarcoplasm
Attachment of ATP to myosin head

questions.solution:
In excitation-contraction coupling, the next step after the power stroke is the attachment of ATP to the myosin head. 

Muscle contraction occurs by sliding the thin filament over the thick filament. The sequence of events is as follows: 

  • Troponin I is bound to actin and tropomyosin. In a resting muscle, it covers the sites where actin interacts with myosin heads. The myosin head contains a tightly bound adenosine diphosphate (ADP) and an inorganic phosphate (Pi).
  • Following an action potential, Calcium ions (Ca2+) are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum and cytosolic Ca2+ is increased. Simultaneously Ca2+ influx also happens through the voltage-gated Ca2+ channels.
  • The free Ca2+ binds with troponin C. This binding will weaken the troponin I interaction with actin and exposes the actin-binding site for myosin.
  • This results in the formation of myosin-actin cross-bridges.
  • The cross-bridge between the head of myosin and the active site of actin causes a conformational change in the head. This leads to the power stroke, which moves the thin filament relative to the thick filament. 
  • A new ATP molecule binds to the free site on myosin. The ATP is further hydrolyzed to ADP and phosphate ions. The binding of the new ATP molecule to the free site on myosin causes detachment of the head of myosin from actin. 
  • This causes a re-cocking of myosin head which completes the cycle.

questions.text: Cyanosis is seen in______
questions.solution:
In stagnant hypoxia, blood flow is very low; so, more oxygen is extracted causing an increase in reduced hemoglobin → cyanosis.

Cyanosis - Cyanosis is the dusky bluish discoloration of the tissues occurring when the reduced hemoglobin concentration is more than 5g/dL.

  • Its occurrence depends upon
    • The total amount of hemoglobin in the blood
    • Degree of hemoglobin unsaturation
    • The state of capillary circulation

Option a: In the case of anemia, the total hemoglobin content is low, so enough reduced hemoglobin cannot be formed.

Option b: In histotoxic hypoxia, the amount of reduced hemoglobin formed is very less because the defect is in the tissue O2.

Option c: In CO poisoning, there is the formation of carboxyhemoglobin, which is red in color obscure the color of reduced hemoglobin.

questions.text: A pressure-volume diagram of the left ventricle is given below. Calculate the stroke volume considering the heart rate as 65 beats per minute.
questions.solution:
The stroke volume of this pressure-volume diagram is 70 mL.

The points in the graph indicate the following events of the cardiac cycle:

  • Point 1: Opening of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-systolic volume (ESV).
  • Point 2: Closing of the mitral valve. The corresponding reading on the graph denotes end-diastolic volume (EDV).
  • Point 3: Opening of the aortic valve.
  • Point 4: Closing of the aortic valve.

Stroke volume is the amount of blood that the heart pumps out with each beat. It is about 70 mL from each ventricle in resting conditions.

In a pressure-volume diagram, stroke volume (SV) can be calculated using the values of ESV (50 mL) and EDV (120 mL):

Stroke volume = End diastolic volume – End systolic volume

Therefore, SV = 120 - 50 = 70 mL.

Cardiac output can be calculated from the given data using the formula:  Cardiac output = Stroke volume x heart rate

Therefore, in this case, cardiac output = 70 x 65 = 4550 mL.
